00001 #ifndef __PK_H
00002 #define __PK_H
00003 
00004 #include "base.h"
00005 
00006 #define RRN_LENGTH  4                             /* Relative record number. 32-bit integer (4 bytes) */
00007 #define PK_REG_SIZE (TITLE_LENGTH + RRN_LENGTH)   /* 4 bytes for a 32-bit integer */
00008 
00009 /*
00010  * This is the internal structure used
00011  * by the primary keys list to store
00012  * each entry: it consists of a RRN and
00013  * one name.
00014  */
00015 typedef struct {
00016   int rrn;
00017   char name[TITLE_LENGTH+1]; 
00018 } PrimaryKeyRecord;
00019 
00020 /*
00021  * This is the structure used everywhere
00022  * to handle primary keys.
00023  * There's the current number of entries,
00024  * the maximum number of entries for which
00025  * there is memory allocated, and the list
00026  * itself.
00027  */
00028 typedef struct {
00029   int regnum;
00030   int maxregs;
00031   PrimaryKeyRecord* pklist;
00032 } PrimaryKeyList;
00033 
00034 /*
00035  * pkListInit
00036  *
00037  * The list's "constructor": allocate memory for the
00038  * list's internal structure, starting with 20 positions.
00039  *
00040  * Returns a pointer to the initialized list or NULL
00041  * if it could not be initialized.
00042  */
00043 PrimaryKeyList* pkListInit(void);
00044 
00045 
00046 /*
00047  * pkListFindByName
00048  *
00049  * Searches for the key 'key' in the 'index' list.
00050  *
00051  * Returns the key's rrn if found or -1 case not.
00052  */
00053 int pkListFindByName(PrimaryKeyList* index, const char* key);
00054 
00055 
00056 /*
00057  * pkListFree
00058  *
00059  * Entirely frees the struct pointed by 'index'. 
00060  * Frees the pointer to the list,
00061  * and only then frees the struct itselft.
00062  */
00063 void pkListFree(PrimaryKeyList* index);
00064 
00065 /*
00066  * pkListInsert
00067  *
00068  * Takes the pointer to the PrimaryKeyList,
00069  * and a string, the pk. Adds the new key
00070  * to the PK index.
00071  *
00072  * Returns 0 if everything went ok 
00073  * or 1 if the key was already in the list
00074  * or if it had any problems inflating the table
00075  * case it was already full.
00076  */
00077 int pkListInsert(PrimaryKeyList* index, const char* name);
00078 
00079 /*
00080  * pkListIsEmpty
00081  *
00082  * Checks if the PK table is empty.
00083  *
00084  * Returns 1 if the list is empty or 'index' is NULL, 0 otherwise.
00085  */
00086 int pkListIsEmpty(PrimaryKeyList* index);
00087 
00088 /*
00089  * pkListLoadFromBase
00090  *
00091  * Loads the primary keys from the registers at 'base'
00092  * to 'index'. Leaves it sorted.
00093  *
00094  * Returns 1 if any problems ocurred, 0 otherwise.
00095  */
00096 int pkListLoadFromBase(PrimaryKeyList* index, FILE* base);
00097 
00098 /*
00099  * pkListLoadFromPK
00100  *
00101  * Loads the primary keys from the primary key index
00102  * file 'pkfile' into 'index'.
00103  *
00104  * Returns 1 if any problems ocurres, 0 otherwise.
00105  */
00106 int pkListLoadFromPK(PrimaryKeyList* index, FILE* pkfile);
00107 
00108 /*
00109  * pkListWriteToFile
00110  *
00111  * Takes the primary key index 'index' and writes it properly
00112  * to the file 'pkfile'.
00113  */
00114 void pkListWriteToFile(PrimaryKeyList* index, FILE* pkfile);
00115 
00116 #endif
